newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: UK's Labour govt sees fruits of new tack on Europe.
newsitem.headline: UK's Labour govt sees fruits of new tack on Europe.

text.p: Britain's Labour government said on Monday its new, constructive approach to Europe was already bearing fruit, with a deal on job creation and signs European states were about to agree to London's demands to keep its border controls.
After just one day of a two-day European summit -- the first full summit attended by Tony Blair as Prime Minister -- Britain appeared to be in the unusual position of getting its own way.
Even France and Germany, doughty opponents who regularly locked horns with former Conservative premier John Major and his predecessor Margaret Thatcher, were complimentary.
"(Chancellor of the Exchequer) Gordon Brown was very helpful," French finance minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn told reporters. "I want to thank him very much."
German Finance Minister Theo Waigel, while being carefully diplomatic, also hailed the change in tone ushered in by Labour's landslide victory in the May 1 election.

"It would be unfair to say that I can work better with Tony Blair or Gordon Brown," he told a news conference. "But it has paid off that I spent at least as much time with Gordon Brown (before the election) than all other socialist policy makers put together."

What Britain is claiming so far is agreement on a pact to promote jobs without any softening of the strict economic criteria for countries who wish to join the European Union's single currency, due to start in 1999.

Blair has said it is "highly unlikely" Britain will join in 1999, but he wants to keep open the option of joining later -- a policy he says is genuine compared to the previous Conservative government which was being pushed into a harder line by anti Europeans in the divided party.
Britain also seems on course to win the "watertight" legal protection for its border controls as other European states move to harmonise their frontier regulations.

British officials said they also expect a letter from the Commission promising a tougher line on quota-hoppers -- Spanish fishermen who have bought up British fishing quotas and take their catches to Spain.
British officials gleefully pointed out that the language of opt-outs and vetos had not been used by Blair to secure agreements which the defeated Conservatives had failed to reach despite threats.

But, resisting the temptation to crow about their achievements or to score points off other European states, Britain's Europe Minister, Doug Henderson, said the deal was a "balanced, a measured agreement".
The new administrations of both France and Britain, vying for the European spotlight after their decisive election victories, both claimed original authorship of the jobs pact.
But British officials dismissed media reports of strained relations between Blair and France's new premier Lionel Jospin.
And other nations began to see a glimmer of hope that easier days were ahead.
One British official, who asked to remain anonymous, quoted Dutch Finance Minister Gerrit Zalm as saying: "Having France and Britain agreeing with each other means we can get things done."
